comment.author: 78936725@N06
comment._content: This is an XC-99. This photo does no justice to how big this beast is. The last survivor is being restored at the National Museum of the Air Force in Dayton, OH. www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/photos/media_search.asp?q=xc-99...

comment.author: 38936533@N06
comment._content: Yes, Nate. You are correct that it is the XC-99. But this was the prototype with no others being built. It was allowed to sit in the elements for years outside Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. Read more about it here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convair_XC-99

comment.author: 78936725@N06
comment._content: Sorry, Wingman. I knew that.  Should have said this is "THE" XC-99. I think its great that they are gonna put this side by side w/ the B-36 that it was based on.  That is gonna be an amount of airplane that is measured in acreage.

comment.author: 80259611@N00
comment._content: I thought this was a B-36 from the thumbnail.

comment.author: 46023761@N08
comment._content: @WingmanPhotograpy: Sitting in the elements for years outside Kelly AFB... like this? www.flickr.com/photos/rjl6955/sets/72157629379589005/with...

comment.author: 38936533@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rjl6955] Yes, Rick. Those pix are amazing. Anybody that stops here to see the above pic should definitely click your link. Fantastic!

comment.author: 37914375@N06
comment._content: That was some monster airplane. I had not seen this picture before. I think I saw a short film on this airplane some years back. I would love to see the restored one in person.

comment.author: 13767332@N04
comment._content: Yes, this is a big ugly flying machine (BUFM)!  It will be great next to the 36.

comment.author: 110778519@N03
comment._content: I remember the stories Dad told about this plane.  Convair didn't have a hangar large enough to perform proper weight and balance, so the CG was somewhat of a mystery.  He said that there were two hugs baffles of water, one forward and one aft of the supposed datum.  The pilot (Ken Tucker I believe) had total control of where the water went on take-off.  Their educated guess as to weight and balance was good as the water was not moved from it's original position.

comment.author: 49487266@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/110778519@N03] We are glad that you have found the set!
comment.authorname: San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives
